results.title: Fed Chair Powell Says Officials Need More ‘Good’ Data Before Cutting Rates
results.abstract: Federal Reserve officials are debating when to lower rates. An interview with Jerome H. Powell confirms a move is coming, but not immediately.

multimedia.caption: The Federal Reserve chair Jerome H. Powell in December. “We think we can be careful in approaching this decision just because of the strength that we’re seeing in the economy,” he said on “60 Minutes” on Sunday.
multimedia.copyright: Pete Marovich for The New York Times

results.title: Don’t Bet on This Former Vegas Mayor Being at the Super Bowl
results.abstract: Oscar Goodman tried for years to lure pro sports to Las Vegas. Now that he’s out of office and the N.F.L.’s premier event has arrived, he has no need for the “Big Game.”

multimedia.caption: Oscar Goodman, in his Las Vegas home, was the city’s mayor from 1999 to 2011.

results.title: N.F.L.’s Rapid Embrace of Gambling Creates Mixed Signals
results.abstract: The league is pushing to popularize and benefit from sports betting while still trying to guard against the potential pitfalls for its players, employees and fans.

multimedia.caption: The BetMGM Sportsbook & Lounge in Maryland. The National Football League is part of a growing apparatus that encourages casual fans to regularly place wagers on games.

results.title: If You’re on Medicare, You Could Save Money on Drugs This Year
results.abstract: Federal law set caps on some spending for seniors who are enrolled in Part D prescription drug plans. Those paying for high-cost medicines will benefit.

results.title: Biden to Sit Out Super Bowl Interview for Second Year in a Row
results.abstract: CBS said the president declined its invitation to appear ahead of what may be the highest-rated television broadcast of the year.

multimedia.caption: President Biden at his campaign headquarters in Delaware on Saturday. In a tradition dating to 2009, presidents typically record an interview with the network broadcasting the Super Bowl.

results.title: Target Pulls Magnet Kit That Misidentified Three Black Leaders
results.abstract: In a widely viewed TikTok video, a high school history teacher highlighted the errors, which appeared in a “Civil Rights Magnetic Learning Activity.”

multimedia.caption: Target said it would no longer sell the magnet kit online or in its stores, and that it had “ensured the product’s publisher is aware of the errors.”
multimedia.copyright: John Taggart for The New York Times

results.title: Joe Madison, Radio Host and Civil Rights Activist, Dies at 74
results.abstract: On the air, he urged politically powerful guests to take action on human rights issues. Outside the studio, he joined protests, including a hunger strike in 2021.

multimedia.caption: Joe Madison in 2015. His activism included a hunger strike and handcuffing himself to the Sudanese Embassy in Washington.

results.title: Job market starts 2024 with a bang.
The Soft Landing Is Global, but It’s Cushiest in America
results.abstract: Economies all over the world are lowering inflation while avoiding serious recession — but growth in the United States stands out.
results.byline: By Jeanna Smialek, Ana Swanson, Alan Rappeport and Jim Tankersley

multimedia.caption: Americans have only slowly spent down the savings they amassed during the early pandemic years, so the money has continued to trickle through the economy like a slow-release booster shot.
multimedia.copyright: Amir Hamja/The New York Times

results.title: Economists Expected a Hiring Slowdown. So Much for That.
results.abstract: Jobs and wage gains remain robust despite the Federal Reserve’s campaign to cool the economy, surprising policymakers and economic forecasters.

results.title: Revisions show even stronger job growth in 2023 than first reported.
Blockbuster Jobs Report Backs Up Fed’s Patience as It Waits to Cut Rates
results.abstract: Given continued strength of the economy, the Federal Reserve is unlikely to feel pressure to cut interest rates at its next meeting in March.
